document.masterDocTitle: Clathria (Thalysias) (Poecilosclerida: Demospongiae: Porifera) from Brazil: New species and redescription of Clathria (Thalysias) basiarenacea (Boury-Esnault, 1973)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Clathria (Thalysias) (Poecilosclerida: Demospongiae: Porifera) from Brazil: New species and redescription of Clathria (Thalysias) basiarenacea (Boury-Esnault, 1973)

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2. MNHN.LBIM.D.NBE 972, Holotype of
Clathria (Thalysias) basiarenacea (Boury-Esnault, 1973)
. Image of Muricy et al. (2011). (Scale bar: 2 cm).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality.
Brazil , Fernando de Noronha Archipelago, Pernambuco States.

Type specimens.
Lectotype
. MNHN . LBIM .D.NBE 972 , Santo AntÃ´nio Bay, Fernando de Noronha Archipelago, Pernambuco State, Brazil , depth 6-10m , Calypso est. 14 , (
Hooper, 1996
). (MusÃ©um National dâ€™Histoire Naturelle, Paris) (Fig. 1 ).

Redescription. Massively encrusting sponge. It has a maximum thickness of 1.5 cm and 5 cm of diameter. Color light-brown after fixed in ethanol 80 % (
Fig. 2
). Surface rugose with a thin detachable ectosome. Presence of incorporated detritus. The oscules scattered over the surface. Body is soft and compressible. Ectosomal skeleton detachable forming discrete bundles of auxiliary ectosomal styles (
Fig. 3
c). Choanosomal skeleton plumoreticulate multi-spicular forming erect brushes in a continuous palisade tangential to surface (
Fig. 3
aâ€“b). Presence of accessory styles included in spongin fibres and echinating acanthostyles in straight or inclined angles present in the principal bundle (
Fig. 3
d). Megascleres . Principal choanosomal styles are thick, slightly curved, smooth shaft and with smooth heads, also usually asymmetrically pointed ( 161â€“258.7 â€“ 344 / 3â€“5.8 â€“ 9 Âµm) (
Fig. 4
aâ€“c). Two categories of auxiliary styles: Auxiliary subectosomal styles I are thin slightly curved, smooth with deformed heads and rounded points ( 206â€“318.5 â€“ 375 / 3 Âµm) (
Fig. 4
dâ€“f). Auxiliary ectosomal styles II are thin, smooth with smooth heads and rounded points ( 100â€“164.2 â€“ 202 / 3 Âµm) (
Fig. 4
gâ€“i). Echinating acanthostyles are straight ( 22â€“51.9 â€“ 67 / 3 Âµm), with few spines (about 28 per spicule) (
Fig. 4
j). Microscleres. Three categories of smooth toxas: two with shallow curvature, in a large size range; Toxas I are rare ( 9â€“16.1 â€“ 25 / 0.5 Âµm) (
Fig. 4
k) and toxas II ( 32â€“46.9 â€“ 68 / 0.5 Âµm) (
Fig. 4
l) and one accolada type , long thin with slightly and shallow median curve; Toxas III ( 129â€“203.6 â€“ 306 / 1 Âµm) (
Fig. 4
m). Palmate isochelae, typical shaped ( 12â€“12.5 â€“ 13 Âµm) (
Fig. 4
n) (
Tab. 1
).
Distribution. So far only known from to Fernando de Noronha Archipelago (Pernambuco State, Brazil ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3.
Clathria ( Thalysias ) basiarenacea (Boury-Esnault, 1973)
. Skeleton: a) Ectosomal skeleton, formed by bouquets; b) Detail of choanosomal skeleton; c) Choanosomal skeleton plumoreticulate with bouquets of auxiliary styles in terminations of principal bundles; d) Detail of echinating acanthostyles. (Scale bar: aâ€”900 Âµm; bâ€”700 Âµm; câ€”500 Âµm and dâ€”200 Âµm).
